title: 103_hr4070
content: SECTION 1. CRIMINAL AND CIVIL FORFEITURE FOR MAIL AND WIRE FRAUD. Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include criminal forfeiture for violations of sections 1341 or 1343. A person convicted of these violations must forfeit any property obtained from the scheme to the United States. Procedures from the Controlled Substances Act apply to these forfeitures. After property is seized and ordered forfeited, the Attorney General will dispose of it. If the forfeited property cannot be located, transferred, or has diminished in value, the court can order the forfeiture of other property up to the same value. "Property derived from a scheme violating sections 1341 or 1343 may be subject to civil forfeiture to the United States. The Attorney General or Postal Service can seize such property with court process, or without in certain circumstances." The government can seize property without court process if it's related to a lawful arrest, search, or has been subject to a prior judgment. A warrant can be sought for property forfeiture under this section. Owners or lienholders can protect their interests if they can prove they were unaware of any wrongdoing. Procedural matters regarding property forfeiture are outlined in subsections (c) and (d). After a seizure of property ordered forfeited under this section, the Attorney General or the Postal Service shall dispose of the property under section 1349 of this title. After seizure and forfeiture of property, the Attorney General or Postal Service shall deposit proceeds in designated funds, with property rights not reverting to the defendant. Upon forfeiture of property, the Attorney General or Postal Service can sell it, with proceeds deposited in designated funds. Any person not affiliated with the defendant can apply to restrain the sale if it causes harm. Rules for property disposition are set by the Attorney General and Postal Service. Upon forfeiture of property, the Attorney General or Postal Service can transfer, sell, or dispose of the property in various ways, including restoring it to victims or destroying it if harmful to the public. The General Services Administration may also take custody of the property for disposal in accordance with the law. The table of sections for chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code, is amended by adding new items as provided by law. SEC. 2. POSTAL SERVICE FUND AMENDMENT. Amends Section 2003(b)(7) of title 39, United States Code, regarding the disposition of forfeited property by the Postal Service.
